user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 is: Controlling expressions shall not be invariant.
Here are exceptions to this rule:
1. Invariants that are used to create infinite loops are permitted.
2. A do-while loop with an essentially Boolean controlling expression that evaluates to false and satisfies the constraints and semantics for an integer constant expression is permitted.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_parse_arguments_:
```c
enum MHD_Result
MHD_parse_arguments_ (struct MHD_Connection *connection,
                      enum MHD_ValueKind kind,
                      char *args,
                      MHD_ArgumentIterator_ cb,
                      void *cls)
{
  struct MHD_Daemon *daemon = connection->daemon;
  char *equals;
  char *amper;

  while ( (NULL != args) &&
          ('\0' != args[0]) )
  {
    size_t key_len;
    size_t value_len;
    equals = strchr (args, '=');
    amper = strchr (args, '&');
    if (NULL == amper)
    {
      /* last argument */
      if (NULL == equals)
      {
        /* last argument, without '=' */
        MHD_unescape_plus (args);
        key_len = daemon->unescape_callback (daemon->unescape_callback_cls,
                                             connection,
                                             args);
        if (MHD_NO == cb (cls,
                          args,
                          key_len,
                          NULL,
                          0,
                          kind))
          return MHD_NO;
        break;
      }
      /* got 'foo=bar' */
      equals[0] = '\0';
      equals++;
      MHD_unescape_plus (args);
      key_len = daemon->unescape_callback (daemon->unescape_callback_cls,
                                           connection,
                                           args);
      MHD_unescape_plus (equals);
      value_len = daemon->unescape_callback (daemon->unescape_callback_cls,
                                             connection,
                                             equals);
      if (MHD_NO == cb (cls,
                        args,
                        key_len,
                        equals,
                        value_len,
                        kind))
        return MHD_NO;
      break;
    }
    /* amper is non-NULL here */
    amper[0] = '\0';
    amper++;
    if ( (NULL == equals) ||
         (equals >= amper) )
    {
      /* got 'foo&bar' or 'foo&bar=val', add key 'foo' with NULL for value */
      MHD_unescape_plus (args);
      key_len = daemon->unescape_callback (daemon->unescape_callback_cls,
                                           connection,
                                           args);
      if (MHD_NO == cb (cls,
                        args,
                        key_len,
                        NULL,
                        0,
                        kind))
        return MHD_NO;
      /* continue with 'bar' */
      args = amper;
      continue;
    }
    /* equals and amper are non-NULL here, and equals < amper,
 so we got regular 'foo=value&bar...'-kind of argument */
    equals[0] = '\0';
    equals++;
    MHD_unescape_plus (args);
    key_len = daemon->unescape_callback (daemon->unescape_callback_cls,
                                         connection,
                                         args);
    MHD_unescape_plus (equals);
    value_len = daemon->unescape_callback (daemon->unescape_callback_cls,
                                           connection,
                                           equals);
    if (MHD_NO == cb (cls,
                      args,
                      key_len,
                      equals,
                      value_len,
                      kind))
      return MHD_NO;
    args = amper;
  }
  return MHD_YES;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function MHD_parse_arguments_:
void
MHD_unescape_plus (char *arg)
{
  char *p;

  for (p = strchr (arg, '+'); NULL != p; p = strchr (p + 1, '+'))
    *p = ' ';
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
suspicious_frags: if (MHD_NO == cb (cls, args, key_len, NULL, 0, kind))
for (p = strchr (arg, '+'); NULL != p; p = strchr (p + 1, '+'))
if (MHD_NO == cb (cls, args, key_len, equals, value_len, kind))
explanation: I have listed all controlling expressions (loop headers and conditional tests) in the provided code that should be inspected for potential invariant behaviour per MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3. Other code fragments need not be investigated for this rule because they are not controlling expressions (they are assignments, function-call statements, string/character operations, or comments) or because the controlling expressions that use variables (args, p, equals, amper) are modified within the loop or depend on runtime results (strchr, callback return values), so they are not statically invariant. The listed fragments are the relevant control points where an invariant controlling expression could occur and thus warrant inspection.
